results.title: Op hop, op hop
results.creator_credit: Pierre Heberrt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A hand-made, scratched-on film experiment in intermittent animation. The images are a group of twenty-four visuals, all non-representational, which arrange and rearrange on the screen in many combinations. The result is a changing pattern of sound and image that has its own rhythm for eye and ear.

results.title: Opera favourites with Placido Domingo and Kiri Te Kanawa
results.brief_description: Te Kanawa and Domingo are two names which rank amongst the most illustious in the world of opera. Both singers bring consummate skill and artistry to their individual performances, but together they form a partnership which is perfectly balanced, achieving a musical and dramatic rapport. All the exceptional musical and dramatic qualities Te Kanawa and Domingo command can be seen and heard in these magnificent performances. Selections are from; Die Fledermaus, The tales of Hoffmann, Agnes Baltsa, La faniciulladel West, Otello, Ernani, Manon Lescaut.

results.title: Open your eyes = Abre los ojos
results.creator_credit: Alejandro Amenabar, Fernando Bovaira, Jose Luis Cuerda, Les Films Alain Sarde, Lucky Red, Producciones del Escorpión S.L. and Sociedad General de Television SA
results.brief_description: Cesar (Eduardo Noriega) is a very handsome young man and an heir to a huge family fortune. At a party he meets Sofia (Penelope Cruz) and for the first time in his life, he feels love. However, his jealous girlfriend causes a horrific accident which leaves Cesar mutilated, his once beautiful face now disfigured. Furthermore, the accident seems to have thrown Cesar into a nightmare world in which he is accused of murder and one from which he is unable to escape. Told in flashback by Cesar who is being held in a prison for the mentally insane, “Open your eyes” is by turns a horror film, a love story, and a metaphysical puzzle which plays with our notions of beauty, faith and truth. Cameron Crowe remade “Open your eyes” as the Hollywood film, “Vanilla sky”. In Spanish with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alejandro Amenabar, Fernando Bovaira, Jose Luis Cuerda, Les Films Alain Sarde, Lucky Red, Producciones del Escorpión S.L. and Sociedad General de Television SA

results.title: Only the Brave
results.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Fiona Eagger and Pickpocket Productions
results.brief_description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ana Kokkinos, Fiona Eagger and Pickpocket Productions
results.description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Vicki is bored with school and she is abused by her father at home. Alex misses her estranged mother and is trying to deal with her growing sexual attraction to a female teacher (well played by Maude Davey). Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives. This tough short film is an outstanding example of a recent Australian cinema. Weaving themes of sexuality, ethnicity and dislocation, “Only the Brave” manages to be realist and elegiac, sensitive and uncompromising, and show how the impact of migration has altered the tradition, landscape and narratives of Australian culture. Mandalis and Kaskanis are knock-outs in their first screen performances and the the film received an AFI Award for best short film and the Audience Award at the Sundance Film Festival. Written by Ana Kokkinos and Mira Robertson.

results.title: Open Cut
results.creator_credit: Phil Burke, Philippa Campey, Australian Film Commission and Film Camp
results.brief_description: Using extensive archival recordings of this once model town, filmmaker Phil Burke revisits his home town of Yallourn and explores some of the issues which led to its destruction.

results.title: Darkman [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sam Raimi, Robert Tapert and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Long before he released “Spider-man”, director Sam Raimi delved into the world of comics when he created the character Darkman, an amalgam of numerous anti-heroes. Liam Neeson stars as Doctor Peyton Westlake, a devoted partner to his soon to be wife (Frances McDormand) and a kindly scientist working on a synthetic skin that will revolutionise the process of skin grafting. There is only one draw back to the procedure; it melts after 99 minutes in the sun. One night there is an attack on Westlake’s laboratory and he is beaten, tortured and placed in a vat of acid. Against all odds Westlake survives, Doctors remove his neurons to alleviate the pain, and Westlake discovers he now has increased strength with a rage to match. Using this newfound energy, he escapes from the hospital to the remains of the lab, makes use of his synthetic skin, calls himself “Darkman” and vows to seek revenge. Making use of the pliability of his new facial structure, Darkman is able to disguise himself to arch nemesis Durant (Larry Drake) as well as reclaiming his fiance from the clutches of another man. Unlike many other superheros, Darkman is not concerned with helping others but focuses on his own cause. Raimi takes great comic delight (if one views “Night of the living dead” as funny) in focusing on the reality and consequence of Westlake/Darkman’s actions, especially as it is wreaked on his two dimensional victims. Music by Danny Elfman. Cameos by John Landis, Jenny Agutter and Bruce Campbell.

results.title: Dark days [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Marc Singer, Palm Pictures, Picture Farm and Wide Angle Pictures
results.brief_description: In “Dark days”, first-time filmmaker Marc Singer has documented the lives of the tunnel-dwellers living in deserted segments of New York’s subway network. Shot in stark black and white and illuminated by a single spotlight, we follow the journey of these dignified and articulate characters from the homeless drudgery of the tunnel to public housing above the ground, which offers some hope for the future. Along the way they strive to overcome drug addiction, rat infestation, and chronic destitution, not to mention tension in their relationships with fellow inhabitants; all while maintaining a strength which shatters society’s myths of homelessness. The tunnel- dwellers acted not only as the subjects for this documentary, but also producers and crewmembers, fighting for their voice to be heard and their story to be told. Featuring a soundtrack by DJ Shadow, “Dark days” is a moving and very human portrayal of life in the bowels of the western world.

results.title: Dark angel
results.creator_credit: Robert Iscove, Elisa Kohn Taub, Big Ticket Television and Spelling Entertainment
results.brief_description: In this made-for-television action thriller, a homicide detective who has been transferred from the Baton Rouge police department to New Orleans under mysterious circumstances is linked to a serial killer who preys on adulterous women. His new superiors assign a female detective to investigate him forcing him to confront his past in order to prove himself innocent before more women are killed. Cast includes Eric Roberts, Ashley Crow, Gina Torres, Linden Ashby.

results.title: Dark rain
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: The work of the Hunter Valley Research Foundation in investigating causes and the remedies for erosion, floods and drought in the Hunter River Valley, and the silting of Newcastle Harbour. Dams such as the Glenbawn will control the river and provide more water for irrigation. Indicates the effect on primary production.
